label: ABC3_hP10_173_b_a_c-001
title: $\alpha$-LiIO$_{3}$ Structure
comments:
LiIO$_{3}$ is known to exist in three forms: 
 $\alpha$-LiIO$_{3}$, stable below 470K: \begin{itemize} \item (Zachariasen, 1931) originally determined that the structure of $\alpha$-LiIO$_{3}$ was \href{current_web_home_dir/ABC3_hP10_182_c_b_g-001}{in space group $P6_{3}22$ \#182}, which (Hermann, 1937) designated {\em Strukturbericht} $E2_{3}$. \item (Rosenzweig, 1966) subsequently determined that this structure was incorrect because of the small sample size, and determined that the true structure was \href{current_web_home_dir/ABC3_hP10_173_b_a_c-001}{in space group $P6_{3}$ \#173}. (this structure) \end{itemize} ~ \vspace{-.25in} 
 \href{current_web_home_dir/ABC3_tP40_86_g_g_3g-001}{$\beta$-LiIO$_{3}$}, stable from 573K up to the melting point at 708K. 
 \href{current_web_home_dir/ABC3_oP20_33_a_a_3a-001}{$\gamma$-LiIO$_{3}$}, stable between the $\alpha$- and $\beta$-phases, with an orthorhombic structure in space group $Pna2_{1}$ \#33. 
 The ICSD entry uses a = 5.485{\AA} rather than the value 5.1815{\AA} found in (Rosenzweig, 1966). This is perhaps influenced bo (De Boer, 1966) (ICSD 14344) and the original work of (Zachariasen, 1931), who both found values nearer 5.48{\AA}.  For now we will continue to use 5.1815{\AA}.
